You are amazing! Your attitude and how you lived your life through all of this was lovely to see.  My story is different. I am a very young 75 year old woman, living at the poverty line, going through my 3rd bout of breast cancer (long history of it in my family) and I also am fighting lymph node cancer. I'm pretty isolated but have my amazing and glorious daughter who I thank God for every moment of every day. I'm 14 weeks into a 16 week treatment. Things look good for the breast, not so much for the lymph node. My chemo nurses are angels and I will miss them when it is all over (although I may have to come back for more, depending on the surgery and what they find). I have excellent insurance, as most poverty medicare people do. But the other expenses are mind blowing. I know this is long so I'll end soon. I just want to remind people that there are so many women - and men -  like me who can't possibly live this kind of life. Look out for us, help us, support us and please, if you can contribute to the Susan G Komen foundation as they do give financial aid from your donations to women like me. Iam so sorry üòû
I did the same thing when I began going through chemo. I'd just had my very long hair cut with highlights when I was told about needing chemo. My scalp hurt sooo bad after the first RCHOP. I had a friend, hairdresser, cut it to a bob also and let my hair fall out naturally. I did buy a couple wigs (one real hair and the other was not). One was long darker blonde and the other was very short light blonde. Moving along, when we'd go out to try to do Xmas shopping, and my husband couldn't find me as he forgot which wig I was wearing. ü§£ It was fun changing wigs up. Spent much less time with my hair. I was actually ok with it and I was so worried. My eldest son (away at university) did NOT want to see me without hair and was likely shocked at my appearance especially being swollen face etc from prednisone. I was always so tiny and my son hadn't seen me for awhile. I adore your attitude. Your family is absolutely precious and warms my heart. Wishing you (all) the very best. I just began watching your videos and will watch all of them. Hugs to you all from North Bay. üá®üá¶

Just a quick message to say thankyou for this totally open and honest video üíñ I'm just at the beginning of my journey and decided to also do the gradual cut to get used to things. I've had super long, thick, bright red hair for over 15 years and so far am finding not being able to colour it the hardest (I'm 53 so lots of white in my roots - not grey as the argument with my grandaughter rages on üòÜ). Got my beautiful daughter to cut 3 or 4 inches off for me recently and today will see me finally letting a professional take it down to a bob. I cut my hair into a bob too and subconsciously talked myself into thinking I might be one of the lucky ones and not lose my hair. I start round 2 of chemo tomorrow and my hair has started to fall out. I'm not ready to shave my head yet but am watching this video to remind myself that I will get through this. This brought back so many memories. Almost 26 years ago, I was diagnosed with stage 3a lung cancer. I was lucky enough to be placed into a protocol - chemo and radiation at the same time. I remember going through the hair loss and my wonderful husband shaved my head too. My head did not like wigs, so I opted for the hat with hair attached, or just went bald. Thank you for sharing your experiences. I know it will help others going through the same thing. I continued to be checked at intervals, and after 11 years, my doctor said I was cured. I did not have to go back anymore. I knit chemo caps for the Cancer Center here, about 30 a year, and have volunteered at the hospital for 9 years. I also was very involved with the Relay for Life where I was Entertainment Chair and on the Board for about 4 years. When you make it through, and that happens so often now, you give back. Thanks again.

I lost all my hair from a severe chemical burn when I was 17 and it ruined my life, I had luxurious hair and then after it fell out I developed severe scalp eczema and it itches so bad I wanna die and kill myself, I'm 39 now and live off ssi aka im very poor, and never driven a car never had a photo id still live in my childhood bedroom single with no love life in 21 years can't work never ever leave my house can't afford treatment anymore and nothing ever worked because its a form of scaring alopecia and it feels like spiders on my head and bees stinging and I feel so ugly and my hormones are way outa wack because I have hair allover my back shoulders stomach chest  I suffer unimaginably every second of  every day for 21 years no support system live in the shittiest town in Pennsylvania I hate it I hate life! Before this happened I was happy successful a great student athlete was deeply in love very popular and attractive and now all my molars are falling out and I haven't gone to the dentist in 21 years because no one can ever see me this way  everything is a nightmare I feel to ugly to speak or have an opinion and feel completely unlovable  I went to the drs many times and explained  everything but they put me on anti psychotics and I hate pills , I just want to be me again and fall in love drive and work have my own place but it'll never happen and it hurts sooooo much I just cry and cry and can't wait or life to be over and I feel like such a loser and people kill themselves all the time over less significant things and I been wanting to die every single day for a good 18 years or so but I just can't kill myself I cut my wrists but that don't work and was scary to me, I wanna live! I want hair and teeth and no gross body hair  but I'm poor and don't know where to turn I have no one my parents are poor too and I'm just lost I haven't gone to funeral weddings nothing in 21 years  I dream of having hair again but then wake up and feel so unbelievably miserable I get physically ill. Sorry for complaining but is all true how would you feel?  I feel for this girl a lot but having lesions and severe itch will literally drive you insane and ruin your life and destroy you as a human being  jesus I beg you please help me please  I need prayers I need a miracle

Thanks for sharing your journey.  Cancer is horrible, but it is survivable. With the support of Eamon and Oso; your medical team and others, you will get through this.    I too have breast cancer. However I've chosen a different route. At 72, I've chosen to do nothing. I've had a great life.  Done biomedical research & worked on breast cancer.... how ironic!  I chose to live alone, no partner nor children. I will miss my solidary life, my rescue cats, my dog, my house & my garden.  I had polio at 2 years old.  Additionally, I have a genetic mutation that has made my life very difficult, if it wasn't difficult enough with the severe scoliosis and other orthopedic issues from polio.  Despite all these afflictions, I did life my way.  Research was my life.  I did it & I loved it.  Good luck on your journey and your life afterwards.   Kaija

Hey ‚Ä¶ I am back. No worries on the hair loss. Mine grew back thicker, fuller, darker (less grey). A small and short price to pay. Get yourself a nice soft very comfortable toque (not itchy) and it will make a world of difference. Amazing how cold your head gets without hair but how much warmth and comfort a good toque provides (like a heavy warm comforter). You might find yourself even sleeping in it. I did. Jello is your friend in so many ways. Find you favorite flavor(s). You will not get tired of jello until this is all over. I am right there with you young lady. Obviously a pretty lose and accepting part of the world.  I really don't know how open and accepting Ontario Canada is.  But my suggestion is NEVER wear the "Bec" wig. I remember the day when I finally had to cut my hair. It seemed such a big step into the world of having cancer. In the end my hair actually started to hurt, if that makes sense and it was a relief in some way. But looking back (can it really be 30 years ago) it was just a step on the road to beating cancer. Obviously it is easier with time and I was a 21 year old lad, so was not a big a step as it is for you, but still felt tough then and as you say you then get all the attention. But you get use to it quickly and when it comes back it‚Äôs really nice.   Speaking as a now 52 year old, I‚Äôm convinced it‚Äôs why my hair hasn‚Äôt fallen out in later life like all my mates ü§£   Good luck Bec‚Äôs.

Tough enough she was diagnosed 1 week before the shelter in place orders were made for COVID-19 and 3 weeks later when COVID-19 shut the world down we never realized 16 months later we would still be taking hiatus at our lake home both for COVID-19 and her cancer.  She was told she couldn‚Äôt have surgery as it was elective and it would be August at the earliest (4 months away).  Welp, through my connections in healthcare we found a university hospital who wasn‚Äôt letting COVID hold up her procedure.   So glad we did‚Ä¶ in three weeks the tumor doubled in size.  Once we started chemo life changed and that is when it became real with chemo and the hairs started falling out. My turn to step up and buzz her head, that is when it became really real besides struggling with trying to deal with all the unknowns with COVID-19 and functioning in a bit of an unruly society.  Life did not go well with every bad reaction to both chemo drugs and 29 radiation treatments over the next several months.  My wife truly was that exceptional patient that experienced every bad and is still on a five year estrogen therapy.  Ok, long story short‚Ä¶. I know Eamon‚Äôs feeling of buzzing your hair.  Fast forward today‚Ä¶ She just had her two year check up and all looks great!  Her hair is back as full as ever‚Ä¶ she has lost 44 lbs and looks like a million dollars‚Ä¶ and while the scare was real, the side affects for her were terrible, today we celebrate the defeat of cancer during one of the most challenging times in our known history.  You got this! Fight the fight! Be strong!  Eamon is your personal soldier to protect and serve!

I had a mammogram yesterday, and they made us get a bunch of extra angles, then they made me do ultrasounds... And now I'll have to get a biopsy soon. Two, actually. Part of me is like, hello, vegetarian who works out every day and spends most of my time van lifing in the countryside, no family history, etc... But then I'm like, if it happened to you... It could happen to me too. And I don't know if this will be any kind of comfort to you, but because you're sharing your journey, I think I'll spend less time searching for "what I did wrong" or how it's "my fault." Because honestly if you got breast cancer with all your love and healthy food and good attitude, it all must be a total crapshoot, and for some reason that's kind of comforting to me right now. Thank God for husband's as good as ours girl!! I don't have cancer but at age 40 I was diagnosed with a connective tissue disorder called Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. At the time we had two teen-agers, lived in a house with stairs that I could not climb anymore, had to give up my job. So, we moved to a bigger bungalow (in the Netherlands most houses are two levels or more), thankfully in the same part of town so for the children not much changed. My job ended. I got more and more medical issues. And my husband never complained. He had (and still has) a busy job, came home and had to cook, do the laundry, went grocery shopping, cleaned the bed's, and became my nr.1 caregiver. I know for a fact that there are a lot of man (and women) who give up. Can't handle having a partner that's I'll. In our case we know that I will only get worse and because it doesn't necessarily kills me, God knows how many years he has to take care of me. And, most important... Stay husband and wife. !! You need to stay husband and wife and you need to keep talking to eachother. We are now 11 years after I was diagnosed. And we are still going strong.  I know that you're relationship will survive this as well. You are a team  So .. I wish you strength and love and that you body defeats this cancer. You are strong, you can do this üí™ Lot's of love from the Netherlands, Dani√´lle üòò

I forgot to tell you that I have my hair again and it's growing very well and thick I have my own eyebrows and eyelashes. So it comes back.
I have Stage 4breast Cancer. I took Chemo from October 2020 to October 2021. I lost my long hair also and I felt overwhelmed from it, because I had always had thick long hair.   Losing underarm hair and other areas wasn't a sacrifice. But, I discovered beautiful wigs...and I got kinda crazy and bought a dark purple bob with bangs and had fun with it!   I'm now on monthly shots and a hormone inhibitor pill once a day.  I feel good and my tumor markers have dropped to very low so my doctor is very impressed with my results.  I think if you can keep a positive mindset and believe that God has great plans for your future, you can have fantastic things in the future. Never give up on becoming healthy again.  No doctor is able to determine your future. It's between you and God what happens.  You are a blessing to others to give hope in how you handle this.  God bless you and I will be praying for you guys in this experience Hang in there  You can do this!

My sister was shocked to find she had throat and lung cancer since she just went in to get a physical as she was now 65., but she beat it.   She didn't loose her hair, but it did thin. Bec, I know you‚Äôre feeling horrible most days. By now, you are probably sleeping a lot more than you would like to. Some days I slept 18 hours. Just when I started to feel a little better it was time for another round. Everything started to taste metallic and the only thing that helped was lemon water. My feet peeled, I felt like I was walking on pegs. My skin broke out in rashes and my face developed huge dry spots. I lost my eyebrows and lashes and it was worse than losing my hair. Everyone could see I was sick. A wig didn‚Äôt matter. But people were lovely to me. Other women who had gone through it would tell me that I would be okay. I‚Äôm here to tell you that you are a warrior and you will come out on the other side of this different but stronger. I am now coming up on 4 years. Mine was HER+. The fast grower. I don‚Äôt know which is harder. Fast or slow, it‚Äôs all terrifying. My oncologist told me that I am cleared because mine was such a fast ‚Äúangry cancer‚Äù that had we not gotten it, we would have known by now. Keep fighting it, girl. You will feel normal again one day. My treatment went for 7 months. I was able to get a lumpectomy. I was barely a Stage 2A but technically a 3A because of the size of the tumor at 2.5cm. Mine had not spread to the sentinel node. You have many people who are praying for you. üíï

Losing your hair is definitely traumatic! I survived losing mine over 20 years ago. I've never had long hair like yours, maybe shoulder length or long enough to reach the band on my bra if I tipped my head way back. I've never really felt like I was much of a girly girl. I've also never had cancer, praise God. But when they removed the bandages after a hospital haircut I came close to coming unglued. Scheduled craniotomy that the doctor said was not an emergency. After a bump on the head several days before getting checked. Getting some of the blood and betadine cleaned up made me feel a little better. I wore and wore the cute little hat my husband brought me. When I got home I handed my daughter the clippers and said finish the job! With it uniform I wore hats and scarves and got comments from customers all summer saying I wish I'd done like you. They had done wigs and apparently tried comb overs and did their best to disguise hospital haircuts, but not clipped the rest off. They showed me their scars from aneurysms and whatever else had caused the hospital haircut. I felt loved as they shared and I think they felt heard like most of their friends had been unable to hear them. You look great bald and hair starting to come back in says it should be a temporary condition. I love your spirit. How you look does not define who you are! Hubby and I agree that it is what is inside you that counts! God bless you.

You are so brave to cut your hair and shave it.  When I went through chemo for ovarian cancer, I could not bring myself to cut it like everyone told me to.  I had very long, thick hair.  I did use a wig, but could never bring myself to cut my real hair or shave my head.   I did use the cold caps for my first few cycles of chemo and it helped slow things down, but did not keep my hair from falling out. Once I was done with chemo it did grow back just as long and thick as it was before chemo. Hugs and healing thoughts to you ‚ù§Ô∏è

Bec, hair is really important to a woman's identity. Losing it makes us stronger as we handle the loss. After chemo, I too lost handfuls of hair, then shaved it...but I kept my bangs (yeah, they thinned but it was fun while it lasted). To me, the worst part was when my head was totally bald. Didn't feel very feminine. But it's finally growing out snd I have a funky baby Mohawk. White and about 2 inches long. No matter how I try to comb it, it goes Mohawk. You'll still have ups and down, but you look fantastic bald, and your wig rocks! Remember how tough you are and that hair is just a teeny tiny minute part of who you are! And Eamon, my Tom is an amazing caregiver/ partner like you. You'll never have a more important and appreciated role in life. ‚ù§Ô∏è

What Cancer Cannot Do.  Cancer is so limited...  It cannot cripple love.  It cannot shatter hope.  It cannot corrode faith.  It cannot destroy peace.  It cannot kill friendship(s).  It cannot suppress memories.  It cannot silence courage.  It cannot invade the soul.  It cannot steal eternal life.  It cannot conquer the spirit.  -Author Unknown  From one warrior to another, you still have the right to quality of life and JOY. Cancer is limited, but YOU ARE NOT. I‚Äôm so sorry this had to happen‚Ä¶ I was diagnosed with low-grade childhood brain cancer two weeks before I turned 10 in September 2013. I had to be in a hospital for 6 weeks for a total of 4 surgeries. (I can still trace the bald line that was my incision from my right temple to the top left side of my head.) I eventually needed 15 months of chemotherapy throughout 2017 and 2018 (which included a LOT of hair loss), and the scar tissue from 2013 led to an epilepsy diagnosis in May 2020 that I still take medicine for. My doctors say that radiation therapy may be in my future, but that remains to be seen.  People with good morals will know that physical attributes do not show a person‚Äôs full story. You wouldn‚Äôt know I was a cancer survivor, epilepsy survivor, or second-degree black belt just by looking at me.  Just remember to never stop being you.

I grew it back a bit but hated it so now I have a number 4 all over. It‚Äôs so easy to wash and feels so freeing. Women can have shaven heads too! I think when you lose hair due to cancer it must be just the whole emotion of knowing what you are going through and having all that harsh chemical going through your body. It's traumatic. I remember when I could no longer deal with my long hair due to severe migraines and got a wedge cut. I've since gone to what they call "the brush cut" and I've been cutting it super short since then. When it gets too long my head starts getting hot and it's time for a trim. One plus is I haven't needed a hair dresser for cuts. I use a clippers with snap on end for length. You might actually like wearing it short when it grows back. It's so good that you have Eamon to share this journey with you.  I did it alone!!  I decided very early on to cut my really long thick hair into a short afro, then one day I noticed how dry and lifeless the remaining hair was and literally plucked it out by the handful.    What I did throughout my treatments was shampoo, condition and oil my scalp as I did when I had a head full of hair.  It's been nearly five years and my hair is growing back. If it helps a couple of beautiful people with their challenges: I had it pretty bad. Surgery, radiation (baldness 1 year), chemotherapy‚Ä¶ and today? No treatment by choice. My strategy from the beginning was to remove its power.  I told few people and when I did, I downplayed it as ‚Äúsomething I‚Äôll finish with sooner or later.‚Äù My buddy wanted to weep and I was visibly disappointed. I explained that I needed him to NOT BUY INTO my need for pity, but focus on my desire and ABILITY TO WIN.  Society can make small hiccups BIG by creating SO MUCH HYPE AROUND OUR PROBLEMS that the molehill becomes a mountain.  I had stage 4 at one point. Yes, it was SCARY to hear my oncologist say, with a white face, ‚Äúit‚Äôs EVERYWHERE now‚Ä¶.‚Äù I‚Äôve been cancer-free for about 4(?) years now, and I‚Äôm just about to go in for another round of more-intrusive tests to reset my baseline.  ‚ÄòLove you both. Half the things you have done on your world adventures scare me more than cancer. P.S. you actually STILL looked quite attractive with no hair. oh sweet Bec.  Your identity is NOT your hair, although you may have felt that way!  I am a fellow cancer survivor.  I once felt that my identity was in my hair, but didn't realize it, just like you.  When the hair started to fall out however, THAT is when I thought I "looked sick".  (and of all things looked like my GRANDPA - - -not my grandma).  I tried a wig, and in one day knew it wasn't the fit for me - - - too hot!  Shaving my head was the best decision:  instantly my eyes looked bigger, bluer, and I looked healthier.  And yes, being bald is a quick identifier - - - it also identifies that you are on the road to healthy!    . . . . I appreciate your boldness, your bravery, your transparency.  From this ole mama (age 60 now, but 42 when I had cancer) . . . . thank you.         KEEP BEING BEAUTIFUL!!!!

Bec... You are so BEAUTIFUL both inside and out. If I were Eamon, I'd shave my head too.  I saw where you were feeling sick and nauseated and that is when you need to get a prescription of Ondansetron. I've been injured on the job and I've had to use both methadone and oxycodone for my "Chronic Extreme Pain". Especially with the oxycodone making me feel nauseated and sick... The Ondansetron is a tiny little pill that dissolves almost instantly just from the moisture in your mouth. It works miracles in helping the nausea and sick feelings go away.  You should really ask your Dr. to prescribe it for you so you don't have to feel so sick and nauseated.   We're praying üôè for you both.  Be sure to take good care of yourself.   We love you guys. I so appreciate your approach to losing your hair due to chemo.  I was 50 yrs old diagnosed with breast cancer, HER2nu positive and Estrogen Progesterone receptive.  It was early.  I had a lumpectomy, chemo and radiation.  The chemo nurse told me I would lose my hair within the first 2 weeks.  Well, day 12 arrives, I am now showering and looking for signs, oh, BTW, I had my hair cut in a short shag cut, day 13 I shower in the morning, all is good, that evening I take my daughter to dance and back home we are sitting on the sofa watching HGTV, and I go to rake my fingers through my hair and it is coming out, and I keep doing it, and daughter says to stop, but I don't want to wake up to a bunch of hair in my bed.  The next day I call my hairdresser for an emergency appt. and he shaves my head. I leave wearing my wig I had bought, but I like wore it 5 times, it was so tight and hot, I ended up wearing wet bandanas on my head, I was going through hot flashes in the hottest summer in south Texas.  All to say, when your hair grow back the first 6 months it will be chemo hair, a totally different texture, mine then grew back thicker, and then thinned out as it was before cancer.  Your hair will grow back, and to have a beautiful wig with Eamons hair and yours is so special.  I am praying for you and Eamon and for your complete healing.  You can do this.
You guys are so fun to watch. I just want to encourage you as my sister just finished 6 months of chemo. She is now cancer free! You are also strong and we are cheering you on, you got this! üòÄ

I love how you still include her and honor her in your daily lives because I do the same. And watching you handle cancer and all it‚Äôs indignities with such grace and brutal honesty is incredible. My mother was the strongest and most amazing woman I‚Äôve ever known. She was on and off chemo for 14 years and I remember her going through the horrible weakness and nausea, the day she shaved her head, preparing beautiful meals for everyone else that tasted like metal in her mouth. But if anyone asked her about chemo she would say it annoyed her because the appointments interfered with her weekly bridge club. And when asked about her hair loss she would rave about how great it was to never have to shave your legs. She laughed and cried her way through it which allowed us to do the same. Eamon, don't think that we're leaving you out! Not a chance! Sharing this journey with Bec - with us,  has opened my eyes in so many ways. You are teaching us how to be kind, empathetic, caring and compassionate while at the same time stepping away to take care of ourselves. I watch you carefully, listen intently as you support Bec and I use the tools that you are teaching to help two of my students who have a younger brother battling cancer.  Sometimes they confide in me how they are feeling (I am blessed that they do) and I am able to acknowledge their feelings, empathize and support them in a way that I could not have done before.  Because of you, I better understand how they feel and have grace when their emotions are overwhelming and they need to vent more than they need to do Math or English or Science! I understand their need to be there to help their parents care for their brother and how that might be why homework isn't done. I can empathize with their situation because you have taught me by allowing me to watch you in yours.  For that, I am forever grateful!  Stay strong, but remember, you cannot pour from an empty cup. Take care of yourself, too!

Bec, I know I've posted this before, but I cannot tell you how much I am learning from your heartfelt and brutally honest posts. Not only the process, but the emotions and courage and strength that you show us gives the opportunity to learn how to be more understanding and empathetic to others going through the same thing.  Today, when my 12 year old student who is battling cancer entered my Zoom meeting, we started with a 30 second dance party, then I told her how beautiful she looked today (she, too, has recently lost all of her hair to chemo)! She was beaming the rest of the class. And at the end, I remembered to focus on complimenting her radiant smile and bravery and told her we were all in her corner rooting for her.  I cannot take away the pain or fear or anger that I am sure course through your veins (or hers), but I have learned from you (and Eamon) how to compliment her bravery, beauty and courage and I'll always remind her that she is not alone, because of you.  And you, my friend, are not alone either! Thank you for sharing your journey. It's making a huge impact in the lives of all of us - and then some!

there's an interview with dr. rhonda patrick - might have been her interview with satchin panda or valter longo on fasting where they talked about the benefits of fasting during chemo - they talked about evidence pointing to the chemo selectively affecting cancer cells vs healthy cells with concomitant chemo and fasting. I'm a nurse and this podcast blew my mind - haven't looked more into it but if I had cancer this is what I would 100% be looking into. I will see if i can find it - it was just a short snip about it in the podcast but they referenced a resource (i think). Something really BIG to look into.  Also referenced the hair cycle & time of day that you receive chemo in one of her interviews - and its effect on hair loss with chemo  So much love and prayer for you both - ALoha

Hey Bec, I just went through my own cancer journey since Jan 2020 (Hodgkins Lymphoma). All the things you said at the beginning of this video, I felt too. I cut my hair in the same process, I made the same decision about the cold-cap too. I never ended up making a wig out of the hair I saved, I still have it :p. My best friend has the *same* kind of hair as me too and donated for me as well!  I rocked some cotton beanies when I was bald-bald, and just went buzz cut as soon as it started growing back (both times, lost it twice)  But I actually had to stop watching your channel a while back because I was so jealous of your and Eamon's hair, and how lucky you were to be healthy enough, and care-free enough, to still travel, and it just hurt a bit to be reminded of what I couldn't do (totally a me problem though, just putting that out there). My daughters hair was coming out in huge clumps.   When she was younger, we did this and she didn‚Äôt mind when we decided to just shave it rather than put her through watching it come out in such massive clumps‚Ä¶.this time she‚Äôs older and was more attached to her hair.  I felt so bad for her‚Ä¶..we weren‚Äôt at home as it began this time.  She was in the hospital for induction 40 days.  She was hit with doxorubicin on day one and that‚Äôs what always takes her hair.  Around the 7 day mark she was shedding‚Ä¶.around day 10 I‚Äôm pulling a lot out when we brush and I‚Äôm lint rolling tons off her pillow.  By day 14 u can see her scalp through her hair but she would still not even allow me to trim it. :( We finally cut it with dull Childrens scissors as she cried in the mirror at the hospital.   I promised her a wig but they were so expensive and by the time I found some help getting one that didn‚Äôt look like a Halloween prop, it was growing in and about 2‚Äù.   She was used to it and said a wig would be ‚Äúitchy‚Äù.  The pandemic allowed her to school from home and avoid stares.  Right now it‚Äôs not quite to her chin yet but she‚Äôs happy with it.   Wishing you the best.  ‚ù§Ô∏è

Hi Bec,  Hope you are doing well on this terrible journey you have been forced along through no decision of yours or anyone else's but I know it's only early days. Nobody deserves to go through the pain of this. As a family we had to face it when our then sixteen year old son was diagnosed with testicular cancer. Fortunately the UK NHS was amazing and fast tracked him to surgery and over five years later he has been deemed clear.   I would just like to respond to one point in your video i.e. loss of hair. My wife developed alopecia totalis about three years ago and although the cause is unknown it was no less devastating on her self esteem than your experience. Fortunately she didn't have the extra burden of a cancer diagnosis. She was worried that she would labelled as a cancer sufferer and although her hair has regrown somewhat it is nothing like what it was previously and still wears a wig. Guys cope with baldness, woman don't as it is not seen by the general population as normal. Perhaps you could give a shout out to all the lonely female alopecia sufferers out there as most of them have little support?  I so wish that you get through this together and I am inspired by your openness and courage. I'm sure you will inspire loads of people going similar situations as you. I am not going to offer you words of advice as I'm not qualified and am sure you have many organisations in Canada like https://twitter.com/macmillancancer in the UK that you will be talking to already.   Love to you both xx

I'm reading a book right now called "Becoming Wise - An Inquiry Into The Mystery and Art of Living" By Krista Tippett. One of the paragraphs she's speaking with Xavier Le Pichon and Xavier says "We have to be educated by the other. My heart cannot be educated by myself. It can only be educated by others...to let them explain to us what happens to them, to let yourself be immersed into their world....You will never be the person in front of you, but you will have created what we call communion....and I feel that is the essence of life." Cancer began eating my liver just like it did to my mom. She passed away at age 57 after being initially misdiagnosed and mistreated for a couple months before going through chemo, losing her hair, muscle, and life. I was 52 when I realized what my body was doing for two years. After seeing what happened to my mom and other friends and family members, I decided not to seek treatment and let it take me. Then I learned about the vegan diet. After 6 weeks of not ingesting animal fats and proteins, my symptoms disappeared and I feel great again. I've been on the vegan diet for over 2 years now and there's no going back.

For the last three and a half weeks, I've been losing my long, thick hair in massive amounts to the extent of having lost roughly 2/3 of my hair. Just wanted to comment on the hair thing, dear hearts--hair cuts, hair loss can be kind of emotional.  It is, after all, a body part, and we tend to be somewhat attached to our body parts, aren't we?  And big changes aren't so much fun sometimes when they catch us unprepared. May I offer this thought: that Flow is a part of who we are, is deeply the essence of our small experiences, and there is comfort in the idea of Flow (or whatever you name it)  and that we may draw comfort in the certainty that "everything She touches, changes...always and again." Bec, you look beautiful! Thank you for sharing your journey.  It is scary losing your hair. I had Covid last summer and that was the most sick I have ever been. A couple of months later, I started losing my hair in huge clumps: in the shower, when I brushed my hair or when I ran my hands through my hair. Going through anything traumatic to the body causes hair loss. I think I lost about 90% of my hair and it has been emotional to experience that.  I know chemo is harder on your body than Covid, but so many of us have had to experience hair loss, so we can sympathize with you! Keep up the positive vibes and we‚Äôll keep you in our prayers.

As someone who has gone through chemotherapy I more than understand what it's like. Looking back it had a effect on my mind. Even too this day I experience what i was told is chemo-brain. Hair loss was my least concern. As it turned out, I didn't loose my hair. But I did loose a lot of what was under my hair. Forced with having to write things down to remember. The experience I would describe as a drunken stupor for a year. And I was before are am I now a person who consumed alcohol. My emotions were also effected. None of the effects were discussed with me prior to treatment. Hence why I have posted here now. So others will maybe read this and be prepared for what's coming. Keep in mind it's something you won't notice till a year are more after treatment. In fact on this date of my post I went in for blood work. I have something called a port implanted under my skin in my neck and chest for IV or to pull blood. I won't know till a week from today what the results are. The unfortunate part is that's my birthday. If cancer is a new diagnosis for you, I know what your going through. I was not supposed too survive. Was given less than a year. That was in 2017-2018. I'm one of those that a 30 year cancer doctor tells you I haven't had someone with your cancer survive from. Yeah, Don t let know one make your prediction. What I have done to survive know one believes. But yet I'm still here. So fu‚Ç¨k the nay sayer's. Your not covering me up with dirt.
This is the first video I have seen from your channel, and I'm going to follow your channel for one reason.  If my mom, my grandmother, and her mother can defeat breast cancer (a multitude of times each), then I know you can do it as well. I believe in your strength, and I can't wait to hear you say you've defeated this thing just as I've heard 3 generation of my family have said. Until then, you still look just as beautiful as my mom, please stay strong.
Much love to you guys ‚ù§Ô∏è

Oh, Bec! I‚Äôve watched all of a minute, and you have me in tears. The fear that others will be able to easily identify you as sick is one my son felt deeply! He didn‚Äôt get emotional losing his hair (at 7.5 years old) - although his dad and I totally did. But when it finally grew back, he didn‚Äôt want to cut it FOR YEARS! When we asked him why, he said he was afraid that going back to shorter hair, people would be able to know that he was sick before. It took some reassuring and picking the right style, but he finally had the courage to do it. And, his hair had gotten so long that there was enough to donate to Children With Hair Loss so that a wig could be made for another child in need. #9 on trending lfg
In 2017, I had to go for radio active therapy for my thyroid. I kept asking if I would lose my hair as it was long. I was reassured that the dose is not close to that of a cancer patient, so there is no need to worry. 3 months later, I was losing balls of hair daily, and the length made it so much worse. I never lost all my hair, maybe about a third. If I let it loose, you could see my skulp, and I would shed all over. There were days I wished I'd cut it or shaved it. But I told myself it's not cancer; no one would understand why. A silent battle no one could even spot.  Stay strong and keep filling the house with more plants and wigs ‚ô•Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è

I was diagnosed with stage 3 Colon cancer in November of 2020, I spent 6 months doing Chemo so I know exactly what you are going through.  I have 3 young daughters (oldest is 6) and I will never trade my time through Chemo for anything else.  I had every day, even if I was laying on the bed not able to move, just laying there with my kids cuddled in watching shows while I slept.  I came out the other side stronger and happier and miss that time with my kids.  Now I get 1.5 hours at night after I get home from work and before they go to bed.  You are brave and you will get out the other side of this stronger and happier than you have ever been in your life.  I admire your openness and honesty during this difficult time.

Bec you are amazing. I got sick and had a pulmonary embolism in 2020 (just before covid hit). It was scary and I struggled with self care, I had my daughter cut my hair down to 2". I found it freeing and so easy to care for. I also want to say Ty for introducing me to Athletic Greens. I'm by far not an athlete, I'm a 48yr old grandmother who struggles with iron deficiency. After 3 days with AG, I've felt better than I have in years. I have energy and even my colour in my face has improved. I'm keeping up with my grandson and getting outside daily. It's help increase my stamina and my mood has improved so much. It's worth every dollar. I'm just finishing my first month and have a new package on the way. As one of the many who had a 'quarantine buzzcut' back in 2020, I actually found shaving my head for the first time liberating in a way I didn't expect. While I didn't have long hair, I've had my hair colored different bright colors for the last 20 years and getting rid of that (something people knew me by) was scary. Obviously in my case it was just something I chose to try and not chemo related, but ultimately it really taught me a lot about inner beauty.   Plus, honestly, I personally think bald women look amazing. Maybe it's just me, but I never automatically think they're in chemo, I just think they're a badass. In fact, the cancer part rarely comes into my mind. I just think: 'Wow, what an awesome, strong person'. And since I already knew you are already an awesome person from watching your vids for many years, your shaved head just emphasizes that even more to me. <3

This is the hardest video I've watched in quite a while. I just want to jump through the screen and uplift you Bec. If you only knew how gorgeous you look with a shaved head!!! There are some people who have perfect shaped faces/heads who can pull off any style they choose and this is definitely you. How does every single haircut look amazing on you?!?! I'd like to share that I have been taking "hopefully" hair-saving medication for about 4 months now. About 2 years ago I began losing my very long, super thick hair for seemingly no reason at all. My hair is extremely thin now and I am very self conscious about it. I hate it. I too might be facing wearing wigs and head scarfs in the future until I can figure out what's causing my hair loss at age 33. No family history of female pattern baldness. I have severe iron deficiency anemia and I'm trying to correct it. I just hope I will find some answers after I have some diagnostic testing done in the near future. So far the medication to help retain my hair, regrow it, and stop the loss is not working. I don't have much hope left at all. It's crazy how much a woman's image and the feeling of beauty comes from her hair. I chopped my hair into a reverse bob at age 20 when I was feeling brave one day after a terrible break up. I felt like a man and very ugly for some reason. I wonder why we are so attached to our hair from young ages. And this goes for men as well. It's devastating for a man when he loses his hair.   I'm so glad that you are feeling a little better about your shaved head now. I hope your positivity persists. We all know you are strong and will get through this. Bec, you're a saint to me....it touched my heart when you asked Eamon if he was okay after he shaved your head in the bathroom. At a time like that you were worried about him and how he felt. You two are amazing people and I wish my husband and I had friends like you. You are both made from special stock, that's for sure!
You look amazing and beautiful without hair. You're a strong loving lady you will get through this. There are no words to make you feel great but know this you're loved and acted for by millions.
Just fyi....you're stunning!

When my mother in law got diagnosed with cancer again (15 years after her initial breast cancer) we sold our house, put our things in storage and moved in to take care of her and her husband who had Parkinson‚Äôs. When she started her chemo and they told her about 14 days, it was 14 days and her hair was also falling out in clumps. She sat down in the chair and I shaved her head. She had thin, very fine hair. I took the cape off from her neck and dropped it to the floor. I didn‚Äôt want her to see it. She lifted it up and took a bunch and put it in a sandwich bag. When her hair came back in it was a beautiful silver and super thick with a wave to it. That‚Äôs been 10 years ago and her hair is still just as thick and beautiful. You got this girl. You will find your own comfort zone and you will be just fine. We love you. Eamon you are an inspiration. I have a guy who is so loving and my rock too.

Hey Bec and Eamon, Bec, I wouldn't say that I completely understand how you're feeling in everyway, because I haven't had the same journey you're having, BUT, I can tell you this: Beauty isn't an exterior thing, it's an interior thing. The exterior is only a compliment to the true beauty of a person. It's the person who is either ugly or beautiful.  I do understand a small bit. When I was in my teens, I was a singer/ guitarist in rock bands. I started growing my hair out when I was 15, and I did it because I was in a band and growing my hair out was my way of rebelling against the norm. I wasn't a shit disturber. I just have never shared all of societies view points. By the time I was 25, my hair was at the crease of my knee length. By that time I was touring the world as a Stage Tech, Instrument Tech, Production Manager, Road Manager, long hair on a guy in the business then was a status in stupid ways.  At around 28, I began losing my hair, which I couldn't except or admit to myself as to myself, my hair was an identity. When I look back on that concept now I realize how damn stupid a thought it was. By my mid 30's I had a skin island in the crest of my head and hid the island with hats. By 40, the island had become an isthmus connecting one side of my head of hair to the other side of my head of hair. And when I would look in the mirror I could see a double reflection of who I really was...a reflection with just a slightly different point of view. That point of view being...that my hair wasn't who I was. That all this time I had been kidding myself...my identity was my skin...hahahahahahaha!!! I turned 50 this past September 2. And last summer I gave myself an early birthday present... I completely shaved my head, not to the skin. Actually I didn't shave it. I gave it a new hairstyle...'the peach'. And for the first time in many years I finally became comfortable in my own skin as I have a pretty damn good shaped head when all the hair is out of the way. And I look at it this way: In truth, I didn't really lose my hair in the first place. Something else happened, which you most likely will never experience. I began to realize that all these years I never really lost my hair, it just migrated south and colonized the rest of my body. The good thing is that the colonies are sparsely located, but evenly spread out. And If I was to shave my whole body and weigh it, it would probably equal out to the same weight as the head of hair I used to have that did nothing but hold me back from realizing who I really was. And that is: A guy who isn't defined by his hair, but by his shine.  For you Bec, you're lucky, your hair will grow back. My hair on the other hand, grows on my back. I think you got the better deal. It's just hair. It's not who you are because you're greater than the sum total mass of your hair. Your Bec. Who you are isn't what you look like, it's who you are on the inside. And you got lucky both ways, Eamon is right. You're beautiful, inside and out. Never forget that. It's just hair Hair today, gone tomorrow, Ya know! Bec, you are who you are not because of your hair. You're who you are because of the joy, compassion, love, empathic, curious, adventurous, thoughtful, spontaneous, caring way that you are you. You don't get that from your hair. You get it from your 3rd brain. Be grateful of that too because there are many people that don't have 1 brain, your gifted, ya got 3, heeheehee, I have a 3rd brain to, mines on the right side of my head just above my ear. I thought about having it removed, but realized it's great to keep my hat on during wind. Everything in life has a purpose, so they say. It's obvious 'they, have never been f'n bald... so I don't give a flying bald monkey's a#* about them. I just care about the good people. The people who make a difference in so many other peoples lives, like you and Eamon do to your subscribers like me. The last couple years there have been many times that both of you have given me some sort of sanity, crazy as that might seem after reading this comment to you. Bec, your short haircut really suits you. Makes you look more mature, yet playful. The shaved head, you have a great shaped head, just think if you were more of a conehead and never knew it. Imagine the shock that you would have had with a very defined pointed head when Eamon shaved you!!!! Ya know what I think of the shaved head look for you?  It's your way of giving breast cancer the finger and telling it go f itself. YA LOOK BADASS!!!!! Your new name is BB, for Badass Bec.  Bec, I hope you got some laughs out of what I lft in the comments for you, but even more I hope the laughter I intended gave you energy, made you feel better about the situation, and helps you on this short journey. You're gonna be alright. Just a bump in the road. You are seriously lucky in that EVERYONE that watches the channel are all collectively throwin good vibes and good energy your way. And luckiest of all, you've got Eamon, who is quickly becoming a legend for how he's there for you through this. He might get his own spinoff channel on YouTube from this. He is in negotiations with YouTube for the rights you know. OHHHHH SH*# EAMON, SORRY MAN, I wasn't supposed to say anything, DAMN.  Eamon, bro, seriously, you are a rockstar for how you've been there for Bec through this. And it's not just Bec, it's also effecting you, but you're totally being what a good husband is supposed to be, and more!!! I know that you guys never read comments, but I took a chance on writing this one.  This video bought back so many memories for me ... Luckily for me, my oncologist was a research doctor and informed me about things that other doctors didn't tell their patients.  Please LOVE you for whom YOU are and becoming, the journey that only YOU can tell because there's no 2 stories that are or will ever be the same. I chose not to join any support groups or do any google/internet searches because they scare the living hell out of you. I was orginally diagnosed as stage 3 (2cm from stage 4), prior to my first treatment I was informed that I was stage 4 which meant that my treatment would be more aggressive. I too had to take the AC cycle which I call "The Red Storm" ... my entire world was turned upside down. I know how you're feeling losing your hair, but you hair doesn't define you, just think ... each day, you can become whomever you want to be (with wigs of course) ... have fun with it. Anyway ... after 4 rounds of the AC cycle, TAXOL was next (which had less side effects and much lighter on the body) ... guess what ... I was allergic to it and had to do the AC cycle all over again for an additional 6 weeks ... I thought my world was ending or God was playing a trick on me, because of the little break between the different types of treatment, my hair had begun to grow back and I had more strength and energy ... back to the AC cycle ... anyway, I did it and I WON THE BATTLE WITH THE STORM, and so can you!!! Virtual Hugs .... here's my email address if you ever want to just talk, I will give you my telephone number if you ever decide to email me (myquerio5@icloud.com) and I will just listen to you cry ... no words, I will just listen. I have been there and I had great family support, but there's nothing like someone that knows exactly what you're going through.  OK ,, my book writing is over ... Hi Eamon (I know that you're the one that's reading this .. give Bec a "just because kiss" on her forehead and say ... "that's for being here with me another day" Love you guys!!!!

I start loosing a lot of hair when I was just 20, then I decided to shave my head. 25 years later, this is something that I keep doing every week. Honestly I have been very happy without hair for all these years. It is super practical. I don't have to think on how my hair looks. Do not need to go and pay for haircuts. I can go from shower to work one minute and a long etc. Also people recognize me easily everywhere, very quickly, and that is kind of nice. When my friends are currently suffering with air lose for many years and trying to cover in different way, I give a fuck many years ago and move on :). This all to say that just look on the bright side. Enjoy this period of time. you hair will come back. As Eamon, say you do not need hair to be beautiful.
I‚Äôve been here for the long haul, and I can‚Äôt wait to see what your future holds. Thank you for sharing your lives with us. Sending you all the love and healing, continually üíñüåàüíñ
‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è
Il never forget the day that i started losing my hair with Cancer. I was 15 when i was diagnosed with a stage 4 brain tumor. I had Radiotherapy before chemo and because they were irradiating my head, the hair started to fall out. And it came out in clumps. I got up one morning and brushed my hair. I remember the entire brush being covered in a thick clump of hair. I cried all day but not because i was attached to my hair. Like u said, its the physical indicator that someone has cancer. Especially for a female. It was like everythong suddenly hit home and became real. Yes, i really do have Cancer. Up until then, i had dealt with my diagnosis by just going thru the motions, doing whatever had to be done not feeling like im sick with Cancer. Now it was literally staring back at me thru the mirror.  As for sleeping with the sensitive bald head, o girl i hear ya. It hurts. I wore a beanie to bed for nearly 18 months. But as u say, there is a plus side to it all. No hair anywhere else on your body. No need to shave. I still to this day 16 yrs on only need to shave my legs 1 maybe 2 times a week. And the wigs are so fun. Somedays id wake up and decided i wanted to be a blonde, others a brunette. I even had a shop assisstant compliment my haircut one day. Mum n i look at each other and smiled. Its not all grey clouds and gloomy days. Sure, there are some really crap ones but you learn to search everyday for something positive to hold onto.

Bec, your video took me right back to when I lost my hair to AC chemo. It was traumatic. But then I grew to appreciate how easy it was to shower, dry my head off and put on my wig. So I‚Äôm a pediatric nurse who has cared for so many babes with cancer. Bald is beautiful. I also suffer from a chronic illness that has disabled me at this moment in life, I‚Äôm 39. I decided almost 2 yrs ago to shave my head because one of my symptoms to my illness is a constant migraine. Funny part, I wear an ice cap nearly all day every day due to pain. Anyway, my illness has taken away my ability to stay fit so my worries without hair was that I‚Äôd look too chunky. Well in the end I said, oh well, hair is hair and that plus my body weight does not define me. My aunt is currently going through chemo for breast cancer. When I was 24 I developed alopecia due to untreated underlying health conditions. At it's worst I had three bald patches, the biggest was 2 inches wide and four inches long on the top of my head. Another was on the side of my head. I ended up having a comb over for two years until it started to grow back in. When you say that your hair is a part of your identity and who you are I understand. It brings me right back to tears in front of the mirror and knowing that if people saw they would know I was sick. I just wanted to say:  It's okay to feel that way. It's not silly or shallow. But you're still a beautiful wonderful person and it doesn't matter what anyone else thinks. You're loved so much and one day your hair will grow back and this will all be in the past. **big hugs**

Been through this (breast cancer) recently and my hair is just now growing back, thank you so much for being honest about all of the things you are going thru, and agree, there is something very empowering about letting go of the hair, and knowing that the chemo is going to do the work, and you just need to be, to let the professionals do the work, and take care of yourself. (and yes it does make taking a shower a lot quicker, so for me, I may keep it short, it makes life and getting ready easier!)  Agree on the cold cap, did not do it as it was more than enough to deal with chemo  I DID do Ice Packs (available on Amazon as socks and glove situation for ease of use, just took them in a cooler to chemo with me) for hands and feet to try to prevent neuropathy, my doc (in the US) was supportive of this and would advise anyone to discuss with their doc to see if it applied to their situation regarding hand and feet ice packs. I ended up pulling all my hair out, as it was all falling out anyway. I found it was cathartic for me. Everybody is very different. My friend who had breast cancer lost no hair. I, on the other hand, lost mine in chunks. Deciding to cut, pull and finally shave my head helped me to feel in control of something when everything felt out of control. With my own journey with cancer, I took one goal at a time. If I can just get through this‚Ä¶then I planned something fun. Sometimes it was just really good food at my favorite restaurant or a drive to a place I‚Äôd never been before around my local area. New plant for every chemo round sounds awesome too.  Side note, if you have massive issues with nausea, Xanax worked for me. Completely stopped the nauseous feeling. Keep up the good work. Your doing GREAT!

Bec, you are a stunning woman. While the experience is different, I fried my hair really badly a few years ago and it started falling out in chunks. I also never thought I was so attached or placed so much of my identity on my hair, but I did. The only solution for my hair falling out in clumps was to chop it all off. Hair isn't just hair, it has a lot to do with our idea of who we are and our feminity. I tried wigs and spent days crying as I lost my curls and couldn't afford or find a wig in my price range that would match my curly hair. I had a lot of issues not feeling like myself.  I was also so ashamed of myself for placing so much of my identity on my hair. It blew my mind that I had attached some much of my self worth to my hair.   This is not something easy, and your handling it with such grace even if it's hard. You really beautiful in and out. I've loved watching you and Eamon's adventures. From the van life to the cabin. While I don't have a van and I'm in a really really small Chevy spark I often take that out on adventures through the southwest now. And have taken that car off-road way to many times. It's seen more dirt than most of the folks I know who own jeeps lol. Your videos helped me be confident to travel alone, to go on adventures. You both are amazing people. And while this probably wasn't part of the plan or journey in either of y'all's minds. You both are going to get through this. Truly you both are wonderful folks.

You had made a comment about how surprised you were that you identified so much with your hair and the color and the length. I can absolutely understand that. Although I am not going through the Health challenge you are going through, I am older and my hair is turning a completely different color than what I was born with. I‚Äôve always had this vibrant red hair that people would stop me in the street and comment on. I remember going through phases in which it irritated me because I wanted people to see me and not the color of my hair. But as I‚Äôm getting older and it‚Äôs fading and it‚Äôs turning more blonde and then white I was so shocked at how I identified with being a redhead. And now that I‚Äôm something different I am so happy how easy it was to just let that go and realize I am so much more than that. You are so much more than your hair, and you know that but it‚Äôs still going to be hard to mourn that loss; temporary as it is. I know you know that but I just wanted you to know that there‚Äôs a lot of us for varying reasons who can absolutely identify with the emotions tied to these external things about ourselves. This video was very human and very touching.  About 2 years ago I went through a very deep depression and suicide attempt. I struggled with my body, sexuality, and beauty in general due to past SA. In recovery I decided to shave my head, I wanted to get rid of the things that made me feel like a sexual object or feel like a "pretty" girl. Shaving my head helped release me from all those negative emotions about my body and let my mind heal. I felt like even though others didn't see me as beautiful I could finally see myself as beautiful.  I had a choice, and you did not really, so maybe it wont be the same, but I hope that you can learn to love yourself even when you feel "ugly" the way I did. I hope that being disconnected from your physical beauty temporarily can give you a deeper insight and connection with your inner beauty.
Sending love to both of youüòÅ

I had stage 2 Her2 Positive breast cancer...stage 3.  I understand your feelings.  I truly do.  After week 2 of chemo...I started to lose my hair.  I just went to a regular barber shop and had them shave it.  I also had a wig ready.  I was definitely a wig-wearer....until I went to bed.  I also lost my eyebrows, eyelashes, most of my fingernails and several toenails.  If this happens to you - don't panic.  All these things grow back.  Most times stronger and healthier.  Just stay POSITIVE!!!  That is super key to your journey and recovery.  Stay Brave!

Back in 2001 I got chemo for Multiple Myaloma.. After two rounds I had to surrender my hair by shaving my head. Cool thing was that Katy Harmon, Miss America was touring the hospital. She came to my room an showed me her crown. All the news networks were following her around and one of them was taking camera shots and gave some copies. I felt so good in that moment. Later in the week I started the process of harvesting my stem cells. One more round of chemo and then they injected them back into my blood stream. Beck

Hi Bec, you look great without hair. Boldness is just another way of hair-due and it suits you.   I don't know if the latest discoveries of way's to treat cancer (or better to help the treat against cancer) is known in Canada, but in Europe they found evidence that cancer cells live on glucose (sugar) and the need lots of it! The human body can survive without sugars and can live on protein and fat. As you try to eat very healthy you may try to live free off added sugar. I'm not a doctor, so inform yourself by asking you doctor or dietician. There are studies with show a very positive effect off low sugar diets, or even intermediate fasting. Some specialist still not believe in low sugar diets as a way to help the fight against cancer, other say some people could not been cured is they continued eating sugars.  Just search the internet for more information if you are interested.

Hey Bec, about 3 months ago I started losing my hair by the hand fulls. It was for no apparent reason, but it wouldn't stop, and it was getting so thin you could see my scalp. I also had long hair all my life, but I cut it off to just above my shoulders. I started taking biotin and hair skin and nails vitamins.  My hair stopped falling out and started filling in and getting thicker. I know it was falling out for different reasons, but when you finish the chemo, it might could help you grow it back faster! You definitely rock the baldness, and Eamon rocks the long hair! Love to you both! ‚ù§Ô∏è ü§ó

I cannot tell you how much this video meant to me.  My teen son went thru chemo several years ago, and I did not anticipate the drama and pain associated with his hair loss. Assuming that because he was a teen boy, he could just get a buzz cut and move on.... but so much of his identity was tied up in that beautiful, blonde floppy hair of his! Of course, I'm grateful and thankful that he is in remission, and he has a gorgeous head of hair now, but I sure wish I could re-do some of my missteps during those hard days. Your video really opened my eyes to the emotional aspect of this side effect from "liquid sunshine." (Adriamycin is a bitch, am I right??) Thank you for educating us all! Much love and best wishes - only good things to come!!

Bec, I have been trying to find the words. I don't have cancer but I do have unexplained hair loss. I've had test done and everything. I never thought about how attached I was to my hair until it thinned. I was self conscious. I cried. I tried new ways to hide it. In the beginning I felt less feminine. Like my hair gave me that femininity. It's weird to explain. I felt your emotions. It took awhile to see that my hair didnt make me who i am. I'm praying over you and your courage. Bec, You're so beautiful no matter what. I remember when my dad lost his hair when he did chemo and then again when he did radiation. My dad had colon cancer back in 2013 and had his right side of his colon removed. He still gets skin cancers and have to get them removed. My dad and I both have Lynch Syndrome which causes some cancers. I actually go March 14 for my yearly cancer screenings and my dad goes this week for his yearly cancer screenings. My dad was so mad and upset when he found out i got Lynch Syndrome but I told my dad it isn't his fault and that I am fine with knowing that I have it as I get to go for cancer screenings every year and at least if they find anything they can get it removed. 2 years ago was my 1st colonoscopy and they found a polyp and they removed it, but if i never knew i had Lynch Syndrome that polyp would of likely turned into cancer within a few years.

I had chemo nine years ago. A day after the first treatment, I was in the shower and shampooing my hair, and it came out by the handful total of it, and it was hard, but I didn't want a wig. When it first came back, it came back curly I loved the curls, but after a year, the curly hair was a little gone. Anyway, one year after losing my hair to celebrate cancer-free, I buzzed it off myself. I had the head for the look. I worked at Macy's in Men's Tailored Suits, so all my clientele were men. I got so many compliments from men. Older men and young men too. Now I keep it buzzed, and at 72 years old, I still get compliments from young men, and now it's in style. Good luck, and you'll get through it just fine, but that chemo is nasty shit. Prayers üôè

I went through chemo two years ago for endometrial cancer. For me losing my hair was not that emotional, I knew it would grow back eventually, but the emotional reaction from other people was surprising. Watching Eamon get in the first cut brought tears to my eyes, it brought memories when I had to cut my own hair because of my own cancer.  I remember messing up so bad that I called my sister who tried to fix it.  I could tell that she was having a bit of a hard time because every time she would comb it, more hair would fall out! Having a bob worked for a few days but it was evident that my hair was no longer mine but chemo hair. My husband told me if it came time to shave the hair let him do it and so on a Sunday he did the honor. I knew then it was time and like you I cried about it, but once it was done I felt like a whole new person and that the next step would be to face my cancer head on with nothing standing in my way, chemo hair included! I learned early on not to worry of what I lost but what l‚Äôm to gain‚Ä¶.my life. You are beautiful even without hair and I hope this part of your story ends on a positive note. I am rooting for you! I wanted to write something separate from the post I posted below on a more serious note. You had asked "what causes cancer" and if I may, cancer is an emotional dis-ease in the body. It is suppressed emotions from past hurtful and traumatic experiences we have not given ourselves permission to feel acknowledge and release and often times do not even remember. When we go through hurtful and traumatic experiences as a child we fragment and with it goes the memories. All experiences are held in our energy field and bodies, physically, emotionally, mentally and spiritually. Over time it festers and becomes acidic to our body, causing an imbalance, so allowing ourselves to feel everything without judging ourselves or explaining away why we should not be feeling what we are feeling is imperative. These energies and body memories must be released outside of the body through your emotions as well as your throat chakra, through expression, through really getting real about how we feel about things. This is not being negative, it is us being honest with ourselves and honoring this part of us. Slapping positivity over hurt only suppresses more. We Love ourselves by allowing what needs to be felt. Once we start releasing we will feel more elated. I have a website with some free information if you would like let me know. I do not want to post anything on it in respect to you and your journey unless asked for. I am an Energy worker/Shaman/Psychic and have years of experience with this. All the best to you Beck and Eamon.

In 2014 I got what I thought was a death sentence when my doctor told me that I have Colon cancer. My wife of 25 yrs couldn‚Äôt handle it so we ended up divorcing. It felt like my world was ending but I Soldier on. I received radiation and chemo which did help a lot and yes I lost all my hair too. I thought that I was over the hump but no so I ended up going into surgery and having a right Colonectomy where they removed my whole right side of my colon. Between that and getting some mental health therapy I‚Äôm blessed and happy to say that I‚Äôm now a happy and cancer free 60 yr old gentlemen. If their is one thing that I‚Äôve Learned is that I don‚Äôt take my time for granted and I celebrate 2 birthdays every year my day of my birth and the day that my doctor told me I was cancer free. It may take some time but it does get better. I‚Äôm wishing you nothing but the best and sending you some good vibes.

It's interesting how much we get attached and have our hair as part our identity. Sometimes you have to find a new way to identify or express yourself. The great thing is that we change and grow to find new ways to be as ourselves. You are blossoming in new ways. My heart goes out to you as you go through this process. My dad had cancer many years ago and went through surgeries and chemo when I was a kid. It was scary for all of us. I remember my dad saying how much he enjoyed the convenience of being bald once he lost all his hair.  I didn't really care if my dad had hair or not. I just wanted him to be around. I send you and Eamon good energy as you continue the treatments.

Bec you are such a courageous and beautiful young woman.  I watched this video with tears in my eyes.  I went through chemo for breast cancer 13 years ago and I remember losing my hair.  I had ACT and my hair fell out the 2nd week of my 2nd AC treatment.  Like you I bobbed my hair after the first treatment and then waited for the rest to fall out.  I thought I had prepared myself and I told myself I never really cared for my hair but when it actually fell out, In the shower, I was hysterical.  My entire body was covered in hair and I was scooping it off the drain in handfuls.  I was sobbing.  I was trying to keep quiet because I didn‚Äôt want to alarm my kids.  I called my friend who is a hairdresser and she came over with her clippers and she got to work.  I must tell you that once my hair was gone it was a HUGE weight off my shoulders.  I felt so powerful and at peace.  I had a wig but never wore it once.  I loved being bald and I never let my baldness hold me down.  BTW, pro tip, I never rubbed my eyelashes and eyebrows and I would just pat them to dry, very lightly, and I kept them throughout my treatment!  You got this girl!  We are all behind you üåª

I'm a Stage 4 Cervical cancer survivor.  After a modified, radical hysterectomy followed by 5 weeks chemo and 28 radiation concurrently, then 2 brachytherapy, I am now 2 yrs cancer free.  It's a hard, life changing battle but when you come out of the war victorious... you'll look back and see how powerful, sharing your journey is to others that might be going through it.  I applaud your courage and bravery ‚ù§ I had weird cravings too.  For 2 solid weeks, I could only eat brownies ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòÇ.  Then of course, I couldn't for a long time. Super personal but I have a birth mark/mole right smack in the front center of my thigh. As a kid I had a more dark olive skin tone because I was always outside, but I did not even wear shorts. Ever. Because of that mole. At the pool when adult swim would be called, I would try to get to my towel as fast as I could to cover up my thigh. I have never been self conscious of the size of my thighs, just that bean sized mark. Now that I am older, my skin is very pale and my birth mark is just as dark brown as is has always been. No one in my life besides my boyfriend knows how much I hated it. Although I don‚Äôt love it now, I do feel like my thigh would look kind of basic without it. My boyfriend says it‚Äôs actually super cute. I get his point too sometimes. He says how he loves that no one else has that same birth mark, and how it makes me more special or whatever. I do get your insecurity of your mole, but tbh I rather have that than a perfectly shiny bald shaven head. You look so beautiful and kinda hot with a shaven head anyways. That mole just says and tells people more about you. You‚Äôre weird, adventurous, resilient, beautiful and so much more. When Eamon says it‚Äôs kind of endearing, he‚Äôs 100% right. I fully admit that I don't know much about this stuff at all, but the way I get through tough times is to "look for the blessings even if they're small", that said to me one of the blessings of this is realizing that you actually like how you look Bec with a shorter bob hairstyle, this is a blessing because when one day you are healed and able to do vanlife again, having a bob would be much easier maintenance living in a van than super long hair ever was. Another blessing is discovering the fun of wigs, so if for example you want to see what you'd look like with multi-coloured pastel hair (just a colour scheme as an example but you get what I'm saying) you'd buy a blonde human hair wig, and there are hairdressers who would dye it the various colours for you or if it's a more simple look you could dye it yourself, lots of options really. That's the perk of wigs, you can experiment and switch up your style as often as you want.

I understand that you are going through a much more intense situation, but a couple months after I recovered from a sever case of the current plague, I lost about 80% of my hair. It was waist length and super thick. The amount you showed after the bath and brushing was what I lost every time I showered or brushed for the first week or two. After that, it just kept getting worse and worse. After about 6 weeks, people were asking if I was going through chemo, and suggesting that I get a wig or hair piece. I didn't do either. I got a layered bob, and ended up with the shortest hair I've ever had in my 55 years of life. Fortunately, it is growing back now, but I kind of wish I would have just shaved it all off and waited to start over. If you've ever seen an animal with a double coat, you'll understand what my hair looks like now. I have a short, thick "undercoat", with a much thinner and longer "top layer".  It's impossible to make it look good right now, but I'm not brave enough to shave it all down to the same length yet. I've spent many a day crying on the floor of the bathroom during this last 4 months, but I never felt as brave as you are right now. Best wishes and keep rocking whatever style you feel like going with.
Your a rock beck you got this!
You‚Äôre beautiful with or without hair. I remember when mine started falling out between my 2nd and 3rd dose of the red devil. I opted to have a friend shave it all off so it wasn‚Äôt a long drawn out trauma. My hair was also in the middle of my back at the time. I soon found out that I was so much more than what I looked like. Good news, I have been cleared by my onco as cured. Mine was triple negative with a 92% proliferation rate. My diagnosis was on 10/1/2018. My onco assured me that if we hadn‚Äôt beaten it, I would have known long before now. Be strong, my pink sister. üíï

I don't know if it's any consolation, but I'm pretty sure many of us are crying with you and cheering with you and incredibly moved by your strength and beauty.   My dad use to give his cancer patients Essiac Tea. It's an immune booster, but it also helps with side effects from chemo. I'm sure everyone is giving you unsolicited advice, and I apologize for being one of them. He just stood so strongly by this option, and I made it for my mom when she was going through chemo from her breast cancer. Blue Moon Herbs is my go to these days (in the states, although I believe Rene Caisse was Canadian‚Äîso you may have better options up your way), you want to do the whole brewing yourself process vs buying the extract to get the most potency. It's become a sort of ceremonial 24 hours when I brew a new batch ‚Äî likely because I feel closer to my dad when I do it. But as you do so many things in your life with intention, I knew you'd appreciate and get that part of it too. I was laughing and crying at this weeks blog, In November last year my hair was right down my back after two rounds of chemo the inevitable happened just like you, oh how I cried the cancer didn't bother me, my hair did, I already had a long wig ready like you (can i suggest getting a Wiggit to keep it on, not those gastly caps) anyway my daughter cut off all my hair, I felt liberated that I'd chosen when to go bald not the chemo, I was still crying by the way even though showering with no hair was still fantastic and sleeping! I still wouldn't go out of the house without my wig on, its now March my hair is 1" already I went out for lunch today for the first time without it which was massive for me, im with you Bec on this journey you are doing fantastic, i was not so good with appetite and lost four stone so eat as much high calorie food as you can while you can, take care now and Eamon you are doing ace luckily my husband is the same prayers are with you both xx

YOU SUIT SHORT HAIR SO MUCH! I loved being bald, because it makes it no fuss, you can literally go to bed right after a shower no problem, personally my head started to irritate me so I was glad to shave it all off when it came to it, I think everyone goes through a bit of resistance I thought maybe somehow I won't loose it, dude you also shaved yours a lot sooner than mine! I ended up putting it off until getting a wickedly wide hair part lol, then I was like ahh ok time for a shave after a day of walking around like that, it was a lot more annoying have it fall all over the place for those going through the same thing, so you save yourself a lot of grief and annoyance :) everyones comfort level is valid though and each experience and reaction is unique and ok to have <3 lots of love P.S. watching the rest of the video you look incredible bald too you rock the boho shaved head! Bec, I don't know your blood type but not all people can eat vegan/vegetarian... "Blood group O According to the blood type diet, someone with blood type O is a carnivore with a strong digestive system and an overactive immune system.  In this blood group, the advice is given to choose especially lean chemical-free meat, poultry, fish and shellfish, oil, nuts and seeds, vegetables, fruit and juices.  Products that are very restricted: dairy, grains, legumes, gluten, certain vegetables such as red cabbage and Brussels sprouts, tea, coffee and cola."
