beauty is in your personality , and you got a lot of that
Hey Bec! I know my journey is nothing like yours, but 4 years ago I decided to shave my head by choice. I kept it shaved and had a short pixie for 2 years before growing it back. Now I'm getting some extensions put in soon! It's exciting! I just wanted to say, even though for me it was by choice, I know that feeling of being so scared of loosing all of your hair. At first, I didn't want to do it, I was so afraid, but my body was asking for it so I decided to honour it because I knew it was important. That being said, you will be experiencing so many new amazing things that will empower you. It is so true that we are attached to our hair like it's who we are and, in loosing it, we feel like we are loosing our beauty. But that's not true. In loosing it, you will shed that part of you that held that belief and you will develop this deeper love and connection to yourself üíú You will discover that beauty isn't outside of you, but inside. Being bald will allow your inner light to shine through even more! Rest assured that you look absolutely beautiful without your hair. When I was in high school, my grandma was diagnosed with lymphoma and lost her hair from chemo. Right after her first round of chemo, before her immune system was completely shot, we went on a trip to Europe because she said she didn‚Äôt want to have to vacuum up all of her hair at home üòÇ. After she left her mark via shedded hair all over the continent, I ended up shaving her head in a hotel in London. Can I just say that Eamon is the best partner you could ever wish for. When your hair regrows, keep it in a short bob, it really suits you. My best friend went through the same (and everyone only cared about her and certainly not about her hair), it started regrowing soon after chemo finished, and she enjoyed experimenting with different hairstyles from short and funky, through mid-length and sassy, until her hair was long again, and stronger and shinier than before, a year later. In the meantime on cold days you can try out different snazzy bandanas, jazzy earrings and wigs if you must. And some cancers are just hormonal and genetic bad luck, but your healthy diet, exercise, fresh air, spirit and outlook are what is going to get you through this in the best possible way. My sister and I didn't really know what was going on with her. I mean we knew that she was very very sick but she always had the desire to keep us out of it as much as possible. She wanted us to keep living our lives and to continue to be happy. When she passed away it was such a shock for us and I've always been kinda sad that she didn't tell us and didn't want us to support her the way we could have done. On the other hand I kinda understand her motive, too. To see you go through chemo and getting liquid sunshine is taking me back to when my mom went through all of it and it hurts to much to know that she did it all on her own. She was so so strong and I didn't even realise at the time. I wish I had asked her more and been there for her more. But on the other hand I get to see now how beautiful and what a chapion my mom was and how strong you are Bec. Thank you so much for sharing your jurney with us and letting us all be a part of it. I am truely grateful for it and I wish you a happy, fulfilling and long life from the bottom of my heart. Lots of love, Kathi

So proud of you, sweets! Those bald ladies are not frail and sad, they‚Äôre the baddest bitches on the planet! When I first heard my doctor tell me that I had breast cancer, I walked back out to the treatment center lobby and looked around at the other women there, trying to see what my future held. There were a sea of beanies, but there were a couple of women who caught my eye. They were bald, had on lipstick and cute outfits. They were smiling, you could tell this was just part of their to-do list. They gave me so much hope for what treatment could look like. As soon as I lost my hair, I made it a point to always go to chemo bald, with a cute outfit and a smile on my face. I wanted to pay that feeling forward to another scared girl. You are doing that same thing on such a larger scale by sharing here. Sending you both all the love! üíï

keep being brave and honest.  it is emotional to cut- let alone lose your hair.  It can be your identity.   since 2003,  i have grown my hair for 2 years (no cuts or trims) and then cut it to a short bob.  with growth 1/2 inch a month, i get 10-12 inches every 2 years.  with each hair cut I donate it to various organizations to make wigs for people who need it for medical purposes.  i can agree, the first shower after a huge hair cut feels SOOO GOOD! This was years ago... I took ice packs and duct taped them to my head. I had a long, blonde mane, thick af. I still lost about 1/2 my hair. People couldn't tell if they didn't know me. I'm not this perfect looking person who needs full face makeup and hair done. IT KICKED MY ASS EMOTIONALLY!!! Like it's just hair, it will grow back and I won't be dead!!! My hair was who I was as a woman. I've had pixie cuts... it's different from combing clumps of hair...I felt like I was being erased. Sooo sick, and couldn't even fake it till I make it. I saved $ on shampoo lol... it gets better, I PROMISE!!!

My soul.....gasp.  my beautiful mom was diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer.  She was never one to focus on hair and nails.  Just a simple lady.  I remember washing her hair when she got sick and her hair was coming out by handful in my hands.  She asked if her hair was falling out and I quickly told her no while trying to hide the handfuls.  But, I had to show her.  It was so painful to show her, as her reaction was much like yours.   It wasn't about vanity for mama and it isn't for you either Bec.  My mama explained to me, it was just the reality and the identity that comes with the bald that made her so emotional.

I went through treatment for breast cancer 11 years ago. My baldness became my badge of courage. Cancer didn‚Äôt take away my hair. My willingness to fight did. My hair would come back, but cancer would not. Being bald was my temporary art project. I actually miss it in some ways. Showers and getting ready were so much easier and faster. No shaving for months on end. No time wasted on hair styling. I could be edgy and free by going bald or quickly choose a wig, scarf, hat, bandana, ‚Ä¶ I hope you have a chance to swim while bald. It feels so silky and magical. I have my hair back, but find that I actually miss the ease and freedom of being bald sometimes. This is a season of incredibly hard things for both of you sprinkled with bits of goodness. Hunker down for the hard and feel the sadness, fear, and anger. Be on the lookout for the bits of goodness, beauty, and humorous strangeness during this time. They have the ability to ease the road you‚Äôre on when it gets tough. I wish you both all the best.

My dad had cancer and I remember him asking me if I would give him a trim.(I loved to cut hair)  So we headed out to the garage and I prepped with my water and comb and scissors. I recently shaved all of my hair off. It felt liberating and I feel more beautiful than I did with long thick hair. Of course, I was able.to make that decision for myself rather than the option being taken from me due to chemo. Personally, I think hair is over rated...especially female hair. So often hair equals beauty and femininity and I'd love to challenge people to let go of that thought process. Of course, it's a very personal journey and experience and some people will always prefer to have long hair vs short hair. Even if someone doesn't love the way they look without hair I at least hope they know they're still just as beautiful and sexy (and are still just as feminine)  I once watched a video of a woman who shaved all of her hair of because her identity and her confidence was so strongly rooted in her hair .. so she decided to do something that felt spiritual and healing for herself to shave all her hair off and to keep it shaved during her journey of confidence and feeling beautiful and happy. I found that to be so inspiring and thought provoking.   This isn't the first time I've shaved my hair off but this time I shaved it without a guard on (so I had almost no hair) and I let my hsuband do it for me. It was actually very romantic for us. It felt so special and sweet.   Thank you for sharing your journey with us. Youre so strong and beautiful. Sending you love, comfort, and laughter

Bec you are becoming a badass warrior with your head shave. I got telogen effluvium (TE) from covid this past few months. Lost about 50% of my hair and my scalp was so sore and tender. It frustrating to see clumps of hair in your hands and not knowing when it will stop shredding but it will eventually. After stopping chemo your hair growth will resume normally in a few months from anagen effluvium. Wishing all the best for you. I'm happy to see you have such a strong support and love around you.

Bec, my son did chemo and lost his hair too.  It was difficult for him as well.  We used visualization to help him through his anxiety during that whole process.  We told him to be grateful that we had a sign the chemo is at work, and for every hair lost meant it was a death of each cancer cell in his body.  We tried to turn every negative into a positive and be grateful.  You are doing the same.  Very proud of you.

Bec, when my mum lost her hair after she started her chemo, it devastated me. I dread to think what it meant for her, let alone me. I was 17. I never saw her hair falling out, she kept it from us and the only real hair conversation I had with her was when she got her wig. I look back on the photos when her hair started growing back. We would joke that she looked like a 15 year old skater kid at times. Her hair has fully grown back now, albeit it came back predominantly grey. She gets it dyed, it‚Äôs healthy and she looks like cancer never happened to her.  You look absolutely beautiful with no hair but when it grows back, however it grows back, OWN IT. The most important thing is your health. All the best. üå∏

I was on your journey over 13 years ago , 13 years let that sink in ..cancer free !. As much as you are in love with each other, supportive etc. may I suggest that you both find someone not family to talk with . Sending so much love to you both ‚ù§Ô∏è thank you for sharing this with us Bec. You are so inspiring. I think SO many of us are so attached to our hair and think without it we're not beautiful. Watching your video I was tearing up along side you and also felt your strength and the release of those attachments and it must feel so liberating. It made me wanna grab some clippers and shave my own head! I am also insecure about what's under my hair, I have scabs from irritated scalp and they never seem to fully heal and it's just irritated in spots and I was so worried that if I didn't have my hair everyone would see it and that thank god I have my hair to hide my shitty scalp. Well, I shouldn't think like that. It doesn't matter!!! Like literally at all! those in my life like my family and friends who see me as beautiful inside and out would never care for one single second about that or if I didn't have my hair or anything so why am I letting myself get so hung up on it. My hair is thinner than it used to be years ago and it made me worried for if I ever lost it, but seeing your strength and bravery and ability to accept and realize our hair does NOT define us, was so wonderful and really helped me.  So again, thank you so much for sharing and taking us along in this journey because you help others as well effortlessly just by sharing. You guys are so amazing and you got this babe. I have been going through my own hair journey in relation to my health issues.  I have ME/CFS and was noticing my shoulder-length hair was becoming a problem in multiple ways. It was interfering with my sleep since my head would get hot while the rest of me was cold.   I was becoming increasingly sensitive to touch, so it would be uncomfortable/ painful if it was poking into my shoulders / neck. I was constantly pushing it upwards out of the way to sleep.   Also, with the severe muscle fatigue and pain, it was adding weight and strain when I had to hold my head up straight, not to mention how hard it was to shower / brush it.   I kept it around chin-length for several months, but still felt it was too much for me.   Then in early December, after posting about it on an ME/CFS page and hearing all the super positive stories of people shaving parts or all of their hair, I got up the nerve to do it!  My roommate helped me shave off the back and sides, and I just kept the top part in a chin-length bob.   I love it soooo much better now. I feel so much lighter and can sleep much more easily through the night. And yes! Showers / baths are infinitely more enjoyable!  When it‚Äôs down it just looks like a normal bob. (I have very thick hair, so it really looks like a normal bob). When it‚Äôs up in a little pony / top knot situation, I feel super cool and bad-ass!   I also feel more androgynous, which feels more like me, especially as someone who has always loved being seen as ‚Äúhuman‚Äù first (rather than ‚Äúfemale‚Äù first), and as someone on the LGBTQIA spectrum. It just feels good not to be confined by my hair in so many ways. ü§©ü§©ü§©  When it‚Äôs warmer (I‚Äôm in Calgary), I may shave all of it, then just grow out the top but again for winter, but it‚Äôs too cold for that now üôÉ  Thanks for sharing your journey! It really is a different experience changing your hair out of medical necessity rather than simply a choice of style, so I commend you for embracing all the moments, whether it‚Äôs the fear, the empowerment, the grief, or the excitement. üôèüèºüôèüèºüôèüèº‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Becca my cousin went through the same thing your going through last year and after all the Chemo and radiation, it's been 6months and her hair has started growing back and it's going to be just as beautiful and long as it was before. Hang in there darlin, your lushess locks will return. Your a strong vibrant, energetic beautiful young woman and I'm praying for you and your recovery..love to you both..‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è
Because you have been in my prayers. I wanted to quickly tell you my story.  I don't have nor have I ever had cancer but I have been on chemotherapy for my auto immune disease.  I have MS. I honestly never knew that chemotherapy was used for more than just killing cancer cells. But it can also be used to treat MS my killing the cells (TCells) that have been damaged by the MS and then I would regrow healthy cells. And hopefully restoring some of the function I have lost due to the disease. Long story short I had to go on chemotherapy for 5 days year one and 3 days  year 2. Along with high doses of IV steroids.  Each year I lost my hair. The first year I shaved my head after losing clumps of hair down the drain of my shower.  It was devastating.  And I felt just like you, it's a marker that your sick. And for the most part throughout my MS journey I have never looked sick. Because I have a disease where it only shows on the inside.  And not on the outside.  People think I'm exaggerating because I don't "look" sick. Never stopping to think that on the inside I was a complete mess. Let them live one week in my body and then come and tell me how I'm exaggerating.   But this is not about that. I want you to know you're beautiful.  Your beauty is not defined by your hair. Hair grows back. Your beauty comes from inside of you. It oozes out of every pour. It's in your smile and in your kindness.  I have never looked at you once and thought oh her hair makes her beautiful.  I didn't even notice ur hair because you shine so brightly as a whole. While losing ur hair is devastating.  It was so very hard for me the first time. Because it really made people look at me with that pity look.  And for awhile that really bothered me. But then I found this strength I didn't know I had. My bald head showed that I'm strong and I'm surviving everything this disease is throwing at me. It shows that I can handle everything with grace and a strong belief in God. I have a wonderful support system who love me at my best and absolutely at my worst.  And I wore my bald head like a badge of honor.  I held my head higher and dared anyone to pity me. So please don't let urself fall into the notion that ur beauty is defined by the hair on ur head. Your crown is so much more bright and beautiful. Your hair was just an ornament.    The second year of my treatment I lost my hair again. All the hair I re grew from the previous year.  But it no longer made me sad. I pulled out the shaver and this time I shaved my own head with a smile on my face.  Because I knew without a doubt that nothing was going to break my spirit ever again.  I wasn't going to be defined by my outward beauty.  But by the beauty that came busting through the top of my bald head. I may not have cancer. But I still understand your  journey.  And I am always going to pray for your healing Bec. Please know that you have a HUGE support system out here pulling for you every day. Love you girl!!!!!Hold ur head up high.   PS... I still wore wigs on the days I was feeling less strong. In fact I am wearing one of those wigs in my picture here on YT. But it was a choice for that moment.  Other days I went out with my fuzzy bald head. My husband named my wigs and would ask me who am I going to be today because he was hoping for Candy. And then I grabbed the wig we called Candy and went out with smiles on our faces.
Bec, I have a mole on my head too and I'm super sensitive about it.  You look amazing bald!! Your head is perfectly shaped.

<3 Dear Bec, I have been watching your videos for a long time and you both are really an example of healthy living. I wonder if you have been vaccinated with one of these C_vaccines. Read up a bit more on what these can do, just to be sure that this might be related. you shouldn't rule anything out. I wish you in any case, that you are soon completely healthy again. I am wondering this because my daughter had "alopecia areate" due to vaccinations when she was 17, which later became "alopecia totalis". She is now 29 years old and lives with it in the meantime. I am therefore now very suspicious of any kind of vaccinations and especially of the current ones. If you lose your hair during this therapy, don't be too sad, because you are a beautiful woman. My daughter discovered at some point how beautiful she is when she styles herself and puts on makeup. She looks super gorgeous. Also, there are now super wigs that look very real. For this time you can help yourself with it, if you think you need such behelfe. But as I said, you are so beautiful that you will discover for yourself how much you can make of yourself. In addition, you will change even more as a person, get to know other sides of you that you have not yet discovered, which will eventually lead to the fact that you will say. There is a reason why I am on this earth. Maybe to show and help this world through your visual reach what is going wrong right now. <3

Hey Bec! I know losing your hair must be really tough. I cant imagine what you are going through but if this makes you feel any better I'd like to tell you that hair cells divide as quickly as your cancer cells. Chemo is made to stop your cancer cells from dividing and in collateral damage your hairs are also affected. But the silver lining to that is that with every hair you lose you kill a few cancer cells. So I'd say let those cancer cells die! P.S. you look hot as bald. You really do and I'm not just saying that. So rock it loveüòòüòòüòòüòò

As a fellow BC survivor, I agree that bald is not only beautiful,  but very freeing! I also didn‚Äôt elect the cold cap. However, another BC survivor recommended the cold packs for your feet and hands to ward off any neuropathy. I have to say, it worked!  I was receiving taxol, and for 15 minutes before and after and for the duration (1 hour) of that particular chemo, I iced my hands and feet.  My hubby and I would bring a cooler with us and a blanket from home. Always looked like we were going on a picnic. üòÇ I purchased specific gloves and booties. You can find them on Amazon. They‚Äôre pricey,  but worth it. Elasto-Gel Therapy Mitts and Booties. In addition, one of my chemo nurses, recommended 600 mg of alpha lipoic acid daily for nerve health. I still take it, after 3 years and likely always will.  She was a firm believer in holistic medicine.  Sending special wishes for strength and healing on your journey. I promise you‚Äôll reach the other side with a positive attitude and gratefulness for every day. üíñ

When I started chemo my oncologist told me that my hair would thin. But not fall out in huge gobs. That's what happened and it got to the point I looked hideous so my husband shaved it off. A buzz cut not completely bald. I was okay with it. The second round of chemo I was a different protocol and again my oncologist told me I would have thinning. But this time it came out a lot. So I shaved it. It has started to grow back. It's a side effect but when you get cured and stop chemo it will all grow back üôÇ I never felt that my hair was part of my identity and I really didn't care I was bald. People don't notice it as much as you think they will and I wear hats almost all the time. Stay strong and positive you are beautiful even without hair!!!!!!!!
Bec you are a beautiful soul and a beautiful women warrior!!!! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏èü•∞ü•∞

My mom always struggled to get her hair to grow.¬† She tried everything & wore a scarf on her head my whole life.¬† I remember being in 2nd-3rd grade, I overheard her speaking to my father about shaving it in hopes it would grow back thicker.¬† She'd been trying everything for years & this was new. I was so devasted at the thought she wouldn't wear her scarf/dew rag anymore.¬† I thought she was beautiful just the way she was & just couldn't wrap my young brain around it.¬†  I was so upset that they had to wait for me to cry myself asleep before they could do it.¬† I woke up in the middle of the night & instantly remembered the night before.¬† Jumped up & ran into my parents room, looking for my mom's head.¬†¬† She had shaved it & i just cried.¬† She just held me & asked me why I was so upset, it was her hair.¬† I thought she was perfect the way she was.¬†¬† I connected her with her scarf/dewrag & being what made her my mom.¬† When she passed 12/16/20 the only Thing I even cared to have was one of her scarfs.  Because she had trouble growing her hair (due to her polycystic kidney disease,).¬† She made us super crazy about our hair, you don't realize how attached you are to something until it's gone.¬†¬† My point is w/out trying to dismiss or discount your feelings or emotions, is that you are so beautiful w/ or w/out hair.¬† I have faith that once your liquid sunshine kicks that cancers ass, yours will be long & flowing in no time.¬† Honor your feelings though.  Love you guys!! Continued prayers and love.
Hii
Aweee!!! Bec you look beautiful bald. I too had long beautiful think hair down to my waist.  I did the bob thing but within I‚Äôd say less than two weeks I was as bald as a cue ball. I have to tell you the worst part of being bald was you get ‚ÄúCold‚Äù faster.   I decided to just go crazy with hats.  My friend crocheted a minion hat for me because I just love those little guys.  Every time I‚Äôd wear it when I went for chemo I‚Äôd encounter a child at the cancer center undergoing treatment as well and they‚Äôd just go gaga over that hat so I‚Äôd end up giving it to them.  The joy it brought to them just beamed through their smiles. I think my friend must of made me 10 of those hats because I kept giving them away.  In all honesty one of the side effects of chemo when your hair falls out is that your scalp feels like you have a very bad sunburn so it‚Äôs very sensitive.   I got a beautiful wig to but truthfully I think I only wore it on a few special occasions because it was just so uncomfortable to wear.  Every person is different so hopefully you won‚Äôt have that side effect. I kinda looked at all the money I‚Äôd be saving in hair care products haha!!  I always tried to find something positive along my cancer journey, for myself it was a way to take that next step into a new day.  Praying for you daily and sending you lots of warm hugs & love from Michigan. Remember your the same beautiful person with it without hair. ü•∞

You are documenting this in real time and I just love you‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è  It‚Äôs a different experience for every woman. In the beginning, I remember when I started chemo, my hair started falling out first two weeks and that didn‚Äôt phase me at all, I just remember saying to a friend, just shave it off. I felt very liberated by that knowing that actually my hair doesn‚Äôt define who I am as a woman (and neither does having a double mastectomy) Cancer certainly wasn‚Äôt going to rob me of who I am.   Yet for my gorgeous mum, losing her hair, eye brows and lashes was so devastating because how she presented herself was a large part of her identity as a woman and cancer stripped her of that, she felt so vulnerable. But she was still a beautiful woman inside and out. It is for many a grieving process. ü§ó  Your hair will grow back and it won‚Äôt be the same. It might be curly and it might be a different colour. you know bec i shaved my head during last year of my med school as i was suffering from so many diseases and was actually struggling with depression.it was hard at first few days probably a day or 2 but then wow man!!!! i felt sooooo empowered that i Don't need to look a certain way to look beautiful or feminine. also i was way more happy because i don't have to comb them thousand times a day, no more hair wash, no time taking hair care ritual, no more hairs on my face while sleeping plus i can try thousands of new hair styles when they would grow back like from bobcut to pixy cut to apple cut to what not n i did embrace each phase of it also it did helped me alot to get over my depression.Also, soooo many boys literally complimented me that i do look cute in no hair or boy cut. so from my experience i can say it's a kind of cool  because now you have got a whole new zone to play around with. by the way you are literally looking badass sexy with shaved head üòç love you girl lots of good health and blessings to you people get well soon üòä love from india üáÆüá≥ ‚ô•üá®üá¶

You are so beautiful, Bec!  You look just as beautiful with your new hair style! Please get some WATERMELON by your next chemotherapy.  You will be amazed how good it will taste to you.  I had very intense chemotherapy in 1979 when I had leukemia.  WATERMELON was the only thing that really tasted good and felt good to me.  Years later after becoming a Licensed Acupuncturist and doing advanced study to work with cancer patients, I learned that watermelon is one of the best and favorite foods for people doing chemotx.  But when doing radiation treatment, ask the radiologist about the timing of watermelon because it can lessen sunburn due to the lycopene.
Btw, that‚Äôs a great wig!!!!
I'm there with ya Bec. I had short hair to begin with and never had the courage to shave my head. I let it fall out and then shaved the few off that hadn't. Interestingly, there were quite a few resistant ones, I thought I looked like a baby orangutan, but not quite as cute, LOL. I told myself at the beginning that it won't effect me, it's just hair, but it ended up practically being the thing I was most upset about. Like you said, it's a glaring marker when you're out in public that you're a cancer patient. You don't want to be viewed as a cancer patient first but as a person first. Big heads are great!! Mine is small and pointy, not that attractive bald, but I still had to embrace it. The head pot for the plant Eamon bought, awwww.

Thank you for taking us on your journey.  My sweetheart was diagnosed with Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma in February 2015.  Shortly after starting chemo, he came out of our back room and said he was going to town to get a hair cut, when I asked why, he said his hair was coming out and it was time  to shave it off.   I  started to get my coat and he said, ‚ÄúNo, I need to do this by myself‚Äù.   He left and I curled up on the bed and cried.  A hour later he was back, rocking a shiny bald head.  This was how he went through all the treatments, the ups and many many downs, with a ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs get this done‚Äù attitude.      I know this journey is hard, but  you‚Äôll get through this.   I wish I could attach a picture of him, he rocked the bald head.

You beautiful beautiful lady
Bec... in 1989 I was diagnosed with stage-4 cervical cancer. I was a young mother my son was 6 my daughter was four and I was told to go home and make an end-of-life plan. I was going through a divorce he did not care. The only person I had was my best friend and next-door neighbor. I had hair below my butt, I did not even tell my mother I had cancer, that's to long of a story. When my kids started noticing  my hair loss I didn't want to worry them, so my best friend shaved my  head. Then she mad a ponytail out my hair and sewed it to the inside of my ball cap.. so when I was wearing my hat it looks like I still had hair underneath my scarf.. that same day she shaved her head and my son asked him if he could shave his, he was six years old he didn't realize the impact he made on me that day of being loving kind soul that he was. And he grew into that same person as an adult. People around me did not realize after my chemo treatment because I had to raise my children the next day I showed up at work and went to work all week.. my friend and her boyfriend at the time would take me to chemo and he would carry me out chemo was super super hard back then. I'd work all week go to the hospital on the weekend get my chemo rest up for the rest of Sunday and go back to work. Because I was stage 4 it was very aggressive treatment, with the love of my friend my children and my determination and even faith I was able to overcome and fight and survive. I was 27 years old, I'm now 59 and still in remission.. on the march 4th I entered my hair salon with hair down to my butt.. and I left with hair above my shoulders and I donated my hair for you... because I can feel what you're going through in your journey with your treatment this is the least I could do to support you..‚ù§

Bec you look amazing w/ short-short hair! I've always wanted to rock the bald look but my head is shaped funny lol the back of my head is flat, my parents obviously left me on my back too often as a baby hehe but I'm digressing; I keep my hair long to cover the back of my head. I can't wear hats or certain headbands cuz they just slip up and off the back of my head.  I'm telling you Bec, you have THE perfect shaped head for short and/or no hair looks!   My daughter has the thickest hair I've seen on any child, glossy and pitch-black; she hated it of course so we cut it short into a bob when she was about 8 yrs old.   We chopped off 11 inches! and since her hair had never been dyed before, we were able to donate it to a company called Locks of Love, a company that makes wigs out of hair that's donated to them for kids up to age 21 suffering from illnesses that eventually lead to baldness. My daughter is now 12 and we're about ready to again cut off another foot of hair and donate it

Funny story for ya Bec.. Been with mt husband for 24 years since I was 14. He really likes long hair. We went through a rough patch when I was in my early 20s.
